author: johnydony
content:
Hello guys. 
I have questions the terms differences between signed execution payload by validators & beacon block. 
These are same data? 
or have some differences?

author: pietjepuk
content: Beacon block contains a field "execution payload", is that what you meant?

author: johnydony
content:
Yeah may be. 
Then beacon block is another term of `slot`??

author: pietjepuk
content: No, a slot is a period of 12 seconds. It can contain a beacon block, but it can also be empty (e g. proposer failed to propose a block in time)

author: johnydony
content:
slot != beacon block. 
beacon block contains execution payload. 
execution payload != beacon block. 
Got it.

author: chris2_2_2
content: <@567563309327581194> Just wanted to say I tried some L2â€™s and the fees were indeed killer. Polygon is cents but rollups (arbitrum) cost me dollars which was very surprising given that I expected it to be cheap. Went back to using polygon. I heard that there going to use other methods to make rollups use less gas in the future but I can only comment on my experience from last month.

author: treyzania
content: optimism is intentionally throttled at the moment

author: pietjepuk
content: Does the throttling have a big impact on tx costs? I thought optimistic rollups were rather linear in how they scale, as opposed to the log-scaling zk-rollups

author: treyzania
content: I'm not sure of the specifics but I believe there is a linear component to the fee structure in both cases due to the L1 data availability

author: treyzania
content: I can look into the specifics in a bit if you want

author: Deleted User
content: On Optimism, there is a 200k transactions / day limit after which they start throttling with higher gas prices. It was 100k / day previously. However, all of this doesn't matter because Optimism never processed more than 53k transactions a day as can be seen here: https://optimistic.etherscan.io/chart/tx

author: Deleted User
content: As to transaction costs, it's quite complicated as they use some form of their own gas, but as a general idea the cost of a L2 transaction is ~98% mainnet dependent. The Sequencer itself charges cents just like the sidechains.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: not sure if they throttle, but Arbitrum Nitro seems to be client changes that'll lead to higher capacity.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
is there something about calldata compression that makes it quite hard, or is it more likely it's just a lower priority for the teams? 

has any ORU implemented any calldata compression yet?

author: treyzania
content:
> is there something about calldata compression that makes it quite hard
there's a few tricks you can do, but they're still special cases

author: treyzania
content: things like ether/erc20/erc721 transfers can be reduced a lot by doing lookups into the state with a proof when doing the fraud game, which adds complexity to the fraud proof verifier, but in the general case there isn't much you can do and have to put all the calldata there and execute it normally

author: treyzania
content: with zk rollups all of that proving happens off chain but it still has that extra complexity

author: treyzania
content: zksync *started* with only token transfers and doing those optimizations so it's already pretty small
